title: consensus/ethash: segfault race
body:
#### System information

Geth version: `geth version`
Commit  ab5646c53 (1.6.7) embedded into a different program

OS & Version: Linux, Ubuntu 16.04

#### Expected behaviour
Private chain syncs ok

#### Actual behaviour
A few seconds into fast sync, it crashes with sigsegv, backtrace below.

I think it might have something to do with concurrency. If I put a lock around VerifySeal so that only one call happens at a time, the problem goes away (and I lose all of the performance). Is VerifySeal expected to be threadsafe? I would expect so. Does anyone have any ideas on how to debug this?

I can elucidate a bit more. In [VerifySeal in ethash's consensus.go](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/blob/8c313eed2614990089114bfe5fea7540f4298752/consensus/ethash/consensus.go#L471), there is this line:

```
cache := ethash.cache(number)
```

cache is a `[]uint32`. Now you would agree that doing this should change nothing right?

```
origcache := ethash.cache(number)
cache := make([]uint32,len(origcache))
for i, v := range origcache {
   cache[i] = v
}
```
Well if I do this (essentially "verifying" that the cache array is valid memory by touching every element) then the segfault happens inside the for loop rather than happening later inside fnvHash. There is definitely something fishy about the way this cache array is handled and it is 100% reproducible on one of my machines (but not the other, which perplexes me)

EDIT: both machines are go1.8.3 amd64

The cache slice is memory-mapped. It's nice that you can reproduce the crasher (we can't). The issue could be related to memory alignment. Can you check the memory address of the slice for a case where it crashes?

The memory addresses are all aligned. I added this code:

```go
        ocache := ethash.cache(number)
	fmt.Printf("XXX cache pointer is %p\n", ocache)
	cache := make([]uint32, len(ocache))
	for i, v := range ocache {
		cache[i] = v
	}
	fmt.Printf("cache was ok\n")
```

Interesting to see that the cache address was fine for two of the iterations through it, the third faulted. My guess is that it is being unmapped while it is still in use. I'll try some sysdig and see if I can catch the unmap syscall

This is a sysdig trace, you can see it writes the "XXX cache pointer..." line to stdout (but not yet the "ok" line, so it is still using that array). A short while later, a munmap syscall with that address is executed. The rest of the sysdig trace is just the panic

@fjl this is an embedded geth, so it's possible that the way I am using the API is different to how it is used in geth standalone (I never see this just running geth console even on the same private chain), but I figured it would be important to report anyway because this shouldn't be possible, no matter how I interact with the API.

It's a real bug and affects geth too. Thanks for digging! In my comment earlier I meant we should look at the data pointer of the slice header (the slice is created using unsafe) but munmap while the cache is in use sounds like a probably cause.
